intro: Bupleurum persicum, commonly known as Persian bellflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its slender stems and clustered, bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and produces small, white or pale blue flowers in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are finely divided and have a distinct aromatic scent, while its roots are often used in traditional medicine for their purported health benefits. Bupleurum persicum thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or gravelly habitats.
